Answer: In a backwards way yes. Historically IP in China is shared. So someone has an idea, others use it and improve on it and society benefits. It’s a great way to have a LOT of people working on the same problems / solutions and refining them. This makes for much more rapid advances. The idea of someone jealously guarding their idea and keeping it to themselves is pretty foreign.That’s why there are (or were) so many IP thefts in China - the taboos against it aren’t there.CCP realised it was an issue and have slowly and surely put protection in place but that’s really only to fit into the western eIn a backwards way yes. Historically IP in China is shared. So someone has an idea, others use it and improve on it and society benefits. It’s a great way to have a LOT of people working on the same problems / solutions and refining them. This makes for much more rapid advances. The idea of someone jealously guarding their idea and keeping it to themselves is pretty foreign.That’s why there are (or were) so many IP thefts in China - the taboos against it aren’t there.CCP realised it was an issue and have slowly and surely put protection in place but that’s really only to fit into the western expectations and so stop the anger from the west.I have to say that IP really is a modern idea that comes out of the US. It wasn’t really a thing and it remains a bit of a mystery to most people as to why using an idea someone else had is so terrible. IP protection works well in an ultra capitalist ultra materialist society like the US but in China it just hampers the advancement and spread of new tech and limits growth.Protection of IP is good for personal wealth but not so good for the advancement of society.

Answer: By initially thinking small, by being focused.I am often asked about PayrollPanda, which is owned by Jibble,Ok, so New Zealand has a population of 4.8m - the leading payroll app there, Smartpayroll, got to 25k customers.Malaysia's population is 33m - but is less developed, equivalent dominance is ~100k customers.That'd be ~US$70m revenue, value ~$3-400m. Not so small.But why not expand across SE Asia now?Ok, say we have a spare $1m, or whatever it is, to allocate.If we put it into, say, Singapore, most of it will be spent developing the infraBy initially thinking small, by being focused.I am often asked about PayrollPanda, which is owned by Jibble,Ok, so New Zealand has a population of 4.8m - the leading payroll app there, Smartpayroll, got to 25k customers.Malaysia's population is 33m - but is less developed, equivalent dominance is ~100k customers.That'd be ~US$70m revenue, value ~$3-400m. Not so small.But why not expand across SE Asia now?Ok, say we have a spare $1m, or whatever it is, to allocate.If we put it into, say, Singapore, most of it will be spent developing the infrastructure.But if we spend it in Malaysia it'd go straight into sales and marketing and so generate immediate revenue.0.1% of businesses here use payroll software. So why chase Singapore when we already have a great product for Malaysia and so many more customers to win here?Singapore would distract us, and risk our position in Malaysia.Take Xero, the world's 2nd largest accounting software company, market cap $6B. Incredibly, 61% of its customers are in its home market, Australia & NZ, which has a combined population less than Malaysia.Think about that. That's the power of focus.Think how Facebook started - Harvard students only. Tiny!In a nutshell,

Answer: First look in the mirror. Honestly. Figure out who you are, what you do well, what you like to do ... and go from there to what you can do, or build, that other people will pay for.It's not justStart with that as an idea generator, and for whatever you come up with, take a good honest look at how much need there is, what resources would be required, and what it would take to develop a business. Do you know the people you'd need? Do you and they have the skills and experieFirst look in the mirror. Honestly. Figure out who you are, what you do well, what you like to do ... and go from there to what you can do, or build, that other people will pay for.It's not justStart with that as an idea generator, and for whatever you come up with, take a good honest look at how much need there is, what resources would be required, and what it would take to develop a business. Do you know the people you'd need? Do you and they have the skills and experience? Can you find new people who do? What would it take to launch this, in actual realistic steps, how much money, what skills, etc?Filter the real opportunities from the ideas. An opportunity is an idea that you can actually execute. You have the skills, experience, team, and resources; and there is a potential market. You want opportunities, not ideas.All of which, by the way, is why people say do a business plan. It's the best filter of opportunities from ideas. And don't take that as the mythical obsolete big daunting formal business plan, but just a lean business plan, sketch strategy, tactics, milestones, and forecasts of sales, spending, and cash flow.Google 'lean business plan' and see what you come up with.

I’m a Londoner, born and bred, so I think like a Londoner. Because I grew up in the system I didn’t have an ability to see what was wrong with it, what it lacked.But in Kuala Lumpur, I see things with fresh eyes - I challenge how things are done. And I’m always comparing. So I see opportunity after opportunity, in Kuala Lumpur and, now, in London.Have you noticed that immigrants tend to own a disproportionately large nDuring my years in London I really struggled to think of original business ideas.However, since moving to Kuala Lumpur I’ve become a non-stop idea-generating machine.The reason? Answer: For a Small Scale, Micro Scale, Cottage Industry Business like Dosa Flour, Sevai, Adai Flour or Pickles -The reason for this is simple. You dont need any formalities or bureaucracy.You can make your stuff at home and your partner can carry it on a cycle or vehicle and a small bribe to a cop can ensure you can sell the product and if it is tasty enough - you can get a sustainable business.In fact it is easier to start a Cottage Industry Business in India compared to China or Singapore.Likewise the same for a Thela or a Pav Bhaji or a Dosa Pushcart. No Formalities.For a Small Scale, Micro Scale, Cottage Industry Business like Dosa Flour, Sevai, Adai Flour or Pickles -The reason for this is simple. You dont need any formalities or bureaucracy.You can make your stuff at home and your partner can carry it on a cycle or vehicle and a small bribe to a cop can ensure you can sell the product and if it is tasty enough - you can get a sustainable business.In fact it is easier to start a Cottage Industry Business in India compared to China or Singapore.Likewise the same for a Thela or a Pav Bhaji or a Dosa Pushcart. No Formalities. Just give free food for the local cops and some “gifts” and you are good to go.In Countries like US - you need a Retail License even for a Hot Dog Concession Pushcart and a number of certificates related to the safety of the Food but in India - you can just hire a vehicle, hire the commercial gas, get some vessels and raw materials and in 2 days- start a Chinese Food Cart.For a Medium to Large Scale business -The Following places are good for starting your own business:-(a) USA(b) Singapore(c) China(d) Dubai(e) Seychelles(f) Cayman Islands(g) Any Carribean Country like Antigua or Barbados(h) Panama(i) Malta, Luxembourg, Liechtenstein

Brin and Page are young, smart and ambitious, and they’re the founders, which doesn’t apply to the leadership of Apple and Microsoft. I explain the importance of thisIn Google’s earlGive it another 10 years, I reckon Google will be the biggest business in the world by far, by market cap.They will leave Facebook, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon in their dust.Here are these tech companies market caps with PE ratios in bracket:AppleAlphabet (Google)MicrosoftFacebookAmazonGoogle are just run so damn well. Brin and Page are young, smart and ambitious, and they’re the founders, which doesn’t apply to the leadership of Apple and Microsoft. I explain the importance of thisIn Google’s early days, they set out to dominate search without knowing how they’d make money. AdWords wasn’t as obvious then as it is now. But Brin and Page knew all along that if they could dominate search they’d monetise somehow.And that has been how they’ve approached everything they’ve gone into. They don’t care about the money as the money will eventually come when they dominate.Chromebook, Android, Google Docs, YouTube, Gmail, their leadership in self-driving cars are all seeds that Google have planted, that will make them huge returns at some point. They’re patient.I mean, despite going in well after Apple into the smartphone arena, they now run 82% of the world’s smartphones. An absolutely incredible achievement. They knew this was a space they had to dominate at whatever short-term cost. And just imagine how much money they’ll make from this in the coming decades.The fact that Google trades at a broadly similar PE to Microsoft just shows how short-sighted Wall Street can be…

question: https://www.quora.com/Looking-at-the-current-state-of-technology-trends-etc-what-are-some-cool-budget-ideas-to-start-next-year-and-what-are-the-best-businesses-to-start-in-2015

Answer: Oh but of course, you can even start with no money whatsoever. Allow me to draw an image for you™️.First you need to secure your own personal living expenses and keep it separate from your business. In fact you might not be able to make any income from your business for the next 3 to 5 years. 95% of startups fail and no one want to invest in your living expense to float yourself first by a job or a side income like freelancing or something.Second, you need to get a startup budget on your own, no debts or borrowing from friends or family nor investments. Create a source of income in order to crOh but of course, you can even start with no money whatsoever. Allow me to draw an image for you™️.First you need to secure your own personal living expenses and keep it separate from your business. In fact you might not be able to make any income from your business for the next 3 to 5 years. 95% of startups fail and no one want to invest in your living expense to float yourself first by a job or a side income like freelancing or something.Second, you need to get a startup budget on your own, no debts or borrowing from friends or family nor investments. Create a source of income in order to create minimium viable product that deliver 80% of the value with only 20% of the features. In order to do that you may need to start another product or a simple business, basically hustle or save whatever extra you make to have enough money to pay for your MVP.Third, now that you started your dream business with an minimal viable product, try to make it a success without asking for loans, or investments from anyone. Just let your product prove itself in the market and use its revenues to support itself. At this stage you need just a market viability proof so you can have statistics and numbers in your brief case.Fourth, baby you are ready to talk to investors, start with friends and family, then angel investors and finaly talk to venture capitalists . Use the money to get the rest of your 80% of features and expand your marketing and distrbution network, grow your team and so on. Never ask money for your own salary.Now you are ready to run with your venture. That’s how ideas float and take off from ground in a nutshell.P.S:P.P.S:P.P.S:

Answer: Well, you can name a lot of them with high probability - so advance in AI, Automation of Simple Works, nanotechnology getting applied to our daily lives and so on.But something that not a lot of people might be seeing is, that the current works on Consensus Mechanisms known from Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, will dramatically change the politics and decision making on the most of the levels. While decision making processes will stay the same, when it comes to a very small group of people, the lessons learned from Consensus Mechanisms will shape the decision making process in modern goverWell, you can name a lot of them with high probability - so advance in AI, Automation of Simple Works, nanotechnology getting applied to our daily lives and so on.But something that not a lot of people might be seeing is, that the current works on Consensus Mechanisms known from Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, will dramatically change the politics and decision making on the most of the levels. While decision making processes will stay the same, when it comes to a very small group of people, the lessons learned from Consensus Mechanisms will shape the decision making process in modern government systems, like The Advanced Democracy (something like the ancient greeks democracy, where only the educated citizens would have vote, but in this model women will also be able to vote) or so called Asymmetric Dictatorship (the totalitarian system in which the decision-maker or a dictator can’t be put in court, because of his law-immunity - the hidden dictator in Asymmetric Dictatorship can, for example, be a simple deputy who is controlling whole decision making process in country - spreading his control over the president and prime minister - something we are seeing in European country - Poland).

Answer: Scissors. Haven't changed in the last 70 years, won't in the next 20.Office printing. There are alternatives to laser printing, but as print declines in importance, I doubt anyone will bother with them. A4 paper going through rollers is here to stay.Lightbulbs. LED will be with us for 20 years and so will the same standard bayonet fittings and bulb sizes.Gas central heating. Burning fossil fuels to heat water and then pumping it into metal heat exchangers in each room is here to stay. Sure, brand new houses won't need it, they will be so well insulated they may not need anything. But 99% of hoScissors. Haven't changed in the last 70 years, won't in the next 20.Office printing. There are alternatives to laser printing, but as print declines in importance, I doubt anyone will bother with them. A4 paper going through rollers is here to stay.Lightbulbs. LED will be with us for 20 years and so will the same standard bayonet fittings and bulb sizes.Gas central heating. Burning fossil fuels to heat water and then pumping it into metal heat exchangers in each room is here to stay. Sure, brand new houses won't need it, they will be so well insulated they may not need anything. But 99% of houses will still use GCH.The computer mouse. It may be implemented differently but we'll still be dragging a palm sized lump to move a mouse pointer around. Oh, and the qwerty keyboard isn't going anywhere either.Turbofan engines. The electric plane is more than 20 years away. The airliner jet engine of the future will be just like the jet engines of today.Wind turbines. Will still be really big with three skinny blades.Domestic white goods. They havent changed in the last 20 years and won't in the next 20.

Answer: 50 years? Thats a tough guess but lets get the crystal ball out here. I have been active in this field for the last 30 years and wish I had another 30 in me with the rate that things are moving right now. If you take the following assumptions it could go a lot further.50 years? Thats a tough guess but lets get the crystal ball out here. I have been active in this field for the last 30 years and wish I had another 30 in me with the rate that things are moving right now. If you take the following assumptions it could go a lot further.If those all play out then I think we will see a continued advancement with O.I. Prosthetics, (Osseo-Integrated Prosthetics) This is where they actually attach the prosthesis through the actual bone with an anchor surgically implanted with one to three surgeries. I have personally seen it to success and it is phenomenal but expensive and a little out of our healthcare bubble in the US at least for the next 10 years or so.For those that are looking for components and sockets there's still plenty of runway available. We are seeing adjustable sockets for above knee amputees that are crazy comfortable and fully patient adjustable like the VAROS socket from Ottobock. We have successfully fit over 20 of these to date. I would only assume that in the next 50 years they will become more implantable, possible microprocessor controlled for temp, fit, dynamic function etc.As far as technology in components we are seeing continued advancements in microprocessor feet, knees and upper limb. The sky is the limit, especially in upper. I would envision a hand that can play the piano and guitar all controlled directly from the brain through TMR type surgeries which are happening today.Lots to talk about, “but overall very cool things for amputees” is the best answer.

Answer: You stop existing.Your body decomposes.The people who loved you remember you for a while.Then, they, too, die, and people mostly forget about you.Your grandfather had two grandfathers. If you’re like most people, you will know very little, if anything at all, about those men. They are dead. The people who knew them are dead. That’s what will happen to you. That’s what will happen to me.Is it sad? Maybe. But I’ll be too dead to notice.

Answer: Yes.As Aubrey deGrey has said, all that is necessary for this to happen is to add one day of healthy lifespan for each day lived. Obviously, that’s far from trivial, but it’s considerably less daunting a concept than eternity.How might this be achieved? It probably won’t happen in one change but via a series of developments. Several biological possibilities look promising:Yes.As Aubrey deGrey has said, all that is necessary for this to happen is to add one day of healthy lifespan for each day lived. Obviously, that’s far from trivial, but it’s considerably less daunting a concept than eternity.How might this be achieved? It probably won’t happen in one change but via a series of developments. Several biological possibilities look promising:On the non-biological front, it seems likely that nanotech will by 2066 have developed microscopic machines that can traverse one’s bloodstream searching for abnormal cells. Once identified, such intelligent nanites could selectively snip and kill such cells or potentially even repair them.The most speculative idea is that we may be able to upload a “person” into a computer as software. Bizarre as this sounds, the logic behind it is this:Kurzweil has advanced a kind of “camel’s nose under the tent” argument for why this will be feasible. Today, no one thinks a person with a cochlear implant is a machine, yet a machine is part of such a person. In the next 50 years, this kind of “cyborg” replacement of failing organs can be expected to accelerate and include most if not all organs. (Big caveat: if one’s stem cells can be used to grow replacement organs, as is anticipated, those will likely be preferred to mechanical replacements, unless one wants “superhuman” abilities—to hear like a cat, or to see like an eagle, for example.)By Kurzweil’s logic, the gradual replacement of a person’s biological systems with mechanical systems will eventually result in a machine that will likelyOf course, such mechanical replacement arguments presume the “person” to be an emergent property of certain patterns of information, and not something different and strange. But that is a different conversation. :)

Answer: Mostly a continuation of the trend we’re on now. As for predicting formats it’s impossible. Most formats get about 10–20 years as the primary. We’re less than 20 years into hardware based digital formats - mp3s had about 10 and now we’re into streaming. Some people think streaming is an ultimate format and they may be right but streaming itself will continue to evolve significantly in ways we can’Mostly a continuation of the trend we’re on now. As for predicting formats it’s impossible. Most formats get about 10–20 years as the primary. We’re less than 20 years into hardware based digital formats - mp3s had about 10 and now we’re into streaming. Some people think streaming is an ultimate format and they may be right but streaming itself will continue to evolve significantly in ways we can’t predict.Here are some easier to predict concepts that are really just continuations of where we are now:Talent: I think we’ll continue to see more and more talent come to the forefront that is better and better (and maybe younger). Globalization means everyone has access to all talent - when i was growing up learning to play bass I was a GOOD bass player for my small town in NJ. I had to go to a summer program at Berklee to learn that I had a long way to go and keep practicing. That competition exists on YouTube now. The downside of that is I can also learn anything to become ‘minimally adequate’ quickly because all information is available at all times, but I think we’ll continue to see better and better instrumentalists pushing boundaries.Style: We’ll see more and more individual and smaller group music. This is already happening - bands are removing band members in favor of tracks and this is going to continue. As more people can create professional quality in their bedrooms they’re going to venture out to collaborate less - smaller and smaller groups and more solo artists - that will mean more influence of electronics.Distribution: As physical distribution matters less and less and digital distribution gets cheaper there will be more and more opportunities to share music - SoundCloud and YouTube the modern example of totally free ubiquitous distribution. TuneCore, STEM and CD Baby allow for pro level. Distribution is available to everyone and everyone can deliver music globally, instantly for very little money. That will get cheaper and easier.Access: This is for all entertainment - thanks to Moore’s...

Answer: I think we are going to head much further into multi-genre music. I think that, in the future, it’s going to be much more difficult to categorize a piece of music. You’ll see a lot more cross-genre collaborations.In the local scene here in LA, I’m seeing a few general trends:1- A throw-back to what worked in the past, namely synth-heavy music and quasi-80s sounds. Usually with male vocals on leads.2- Female singer-songwriters with some extra electricity, leaning towards what was popular in the early 2000s. They aren’t quite cranking the gain to 11, but they are using electric guitars more thanI think we are going to head much further into multi-genre music. I think that, in the future, it’s going to be much more difficult to categorize a piece of music. You’ll see a lot more cross-genre collaborations.In the local scene here in LA, I’m seeing a few general trends:1- A throw-back to what worked in the past, namely synth-heavy music and quasi-80s sounds. Usually with male vocals on leads.2- Female singer-songwriters with some extra electricity, leaning towards what was popular in the early 2000s. They aren’t quite cranking the gain to 11, but they are using electric guitars more than acoustic.3- Ableton is huge right now and everyone is learning it and using it on stage, either in whole or in part. Nearly everyone has an Apple computer on stage with them, even if they have drummers.4- Bands with mixed genders. It’s not uncommon to see guys and girls on stage together now. There aren’t many “chick bands” like you would see in the past, though some still exist, obviously.5- Male rappers seem to be trending more towards party anthems than hard-core gangster rap. It’s just as vulgar as before, so don’t expect the lyrics to get any more clean.6- Female rappers are stepping up their game very hard, not giving any quarter, and starting to go much more gangster.

Answer: Technology has already rendered most of what you hear on the radio artificial as far as I'm concerned. It's all overdubbed and overproduced and impossible to replicate in a live setting. It's one of the things that has turned me off from music, but has turned a lot of people on to it.I'm not sure how much further you can go from basically all music being synthetic and digital, which is where we already are. Every modern song can ultimately be replicated using a digital keyboard and some mixing equipment, and through no other method.

Answer: Well, for one, stop calling yourself web developer, start calling yourself developer.And it is machine learning you should look into, tensor flow and these things.But all programming languages have ML libraries, if they do what you want to, then there is no need to get deep, in the same fashion as, not everyone needs to write their own database servers.But change the way you look at yourself. Call yourself developer, don’t limit yourself, don’t say “just a developer” either. Take pride in what you do. Know that take 100 random people, and you might be the only one who has what it takes to progWell, for one, stop calling yourself web developer, start calling yourself developer.And it is machine learning you should look into, tensor flow and these things.But all programming languages have ML libraries, if they do what you want to, then there is no need to get deep, in the same fashion as, not everyone needs to write their own database servers.But change the way you look at yourself. Call yourself developer, don’t limit yourself, don’t say “just a developer” either. Take pride in what you do. Know that take 100 random people, and you might be the only one who has what it takes to program. You are a professional. Act like one.Read books, blogs. Get your hands on anything regarding machine learning, find out if it actually is what you need, you might not need to use it.Being a professional developer is a full time work, and you should be constantly learning and re-learning. One programmer even went that far as to say, what are you doing at 8 o’clock in the evening, that is what you are. If you are coding or learning to code, that is what you are, if you are watching TV, that is what you are, a TV watcher.

Answer: Will AI replace web developers?Nope.Is learning web development in 2022 good?Eh.I think web development is oversaturated at the junior level. Beginners seem to gravitate towards web development and I think we’re ending up with too many junior developers applying for too few jobs.I noticed this on Upwork, I could get app development gigs, desktop software gigs, but never really got any web work, just too many people applying for the same stuff charging far less than me.If you’re looking to apply for jobs as a junior in a year or so, personally I’d say learn anything other than web stuff, it’s tWill AI replace web developers?Nope.Is learning web development in 2022 good?Eh.I think web development is oversaturated at the junior level. Beginners seem to gravitate towards web development and I think we’re ending up with too many junior developers applying for too few jobs.I noticed this on Upwork, I could get app development gigs, desktop software gigs, but never really got any web work, just too many people applying for the same stuff charging far less than me.If you’re looking to apply for jobs as a junior in a year or so, personally I’d say learn anything other than web stuff, it’s too crowded.
